learning_outcomes.description: have developed an understanding of the major modern techniques for molecular computation: statistical mechanics, classical mechanics, molecular dynamics and quantum mechanics.

have developed an understanding of the interplay between thermal motion, thermodynamics, kinetics, classical mechanics, and quantum mechanics, and how these can be used to predict structure and reactivity in molecular systems.
have developed a knowledge and appreciation of the concepts of physical chemistry, by understanding the way that energy is distributed in chemical systems.
have developed practical skills in the area of computational chemistry and molecular simulations.
solve problems in physical chemistry through application of principles taught in lectures and practiced in problem solving sessions and computer workshops.

assessments.task_description:
Each module includes a series of computer laboratory practical sessions. The sessions may include standalone (single-week) and/or extended (mullti-week) investigations, depending on the module (details will be provided by the lecturer). For each module, a report on the laboratory activities is to be completed.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: At the discretion of the individual lecturer, each laboratory report will either be completed during a designated practical session and submitted before the student leaves, or submitted through Blackboard (either through a direct Blackboard submission link or through a Turnitin link on Blackboard; lecturers will advise). Details of the submission process for each report will be advised by the lecturer.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The exam will cover all modules of the course. More information about the exam will be provided during teaching activities and/or on Blackboard. 

Please note: In certain previous years, the CHEM3011 exam paper included a data sheet containing equations and physical constants. This year, a data sheet will NOT be provided. Instead, students will be allowed to bring to the exam one A4 sheet of handwritten or typed notes (double sided). The sheet of notes can contain any relevant information the student wishes to have access to during the exam (equations, physical constants, and/or other information), provided that it is handwritten or typed. Students are encouraged to keep this in mind when reviewing past exam papers from previous years, and when preparing for the exam.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
